p: As a way of identifying coronavirus-related R&D areas, the co-occurrence matrix was made in terms of the ASJC code (All Science Journal Classification Codes) of Scopus by using the Vantage Point ® system (Search Technology, Inc., Norcross, GA, USA) as demonstrated in [ 15]. From the single standard’s perspective, the ASJC code was previously assigned to all the projects in the global R&D database that employed the machine learning approach to classify the different R&D projects that stemmed from the US, the EU, and Japan [ 15]. The number of data utilized by Korea, which has the characteristics of the centralized database, was as high as that used by the US. It may cause a “home advantage” bias [ 26, 27]. Thus, the data of Korea excluded the making of a co-occurrence matrix.
